posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: My team is currently having issues with our Canivore module. The canivore is connected to the RoboRio via a usb-A to usb-C cable. 4 CanCoders are the only devices connected to it. We are using NEO’s for drive and steering. Randomly the Canivore will drop out and cause a glitch when it resets. I have seen it happen on the work bench, The LED will be green but then it will flash red once and then back to green.  Once it happens once it has to be unplugged from power and re connected for the fault to go away.  Please throw some ideas at me.

posts.name: Michael Jansen
posts.cooked: Not sure if its the same thing you’re experiencing but we had something similar happening at our last event where the CANivore would momentarily disconnect. Swapping out the RIO resolved the issue for us, so it was likely a dying USB port.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked: Do you have anything else plugged into the USB ports on the Rio?

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: Yes, we have a USB camera connected into the second USB port.

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: Thank you, I will try swapping it out tonight when we go to the robotics lab.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
I’m curious - is having another device plugged into the USB really an issue?

I only ask because we are having an occasional “Can frame stale” message on our bus.  We literally went through the entire robot yesterday from end to end and checked or re-did every termination and connection without an improvement.

We didn’t have it at the first competition we went to.  While we’ve added a number of motors to the bus, we also added a USB driver camera.  I never even thought to unplug it as part of the troubleshooting.

posts.name: Melchior Vester
posts.cooked: Check the internal resistance of your CANivore CAN bus. Do you have a ending terminating resistor? Assuming you do, how is it connected? Might be worth changing that out as well.

We also had this issue occur randomly beginning at our first event. We even swapped our Rio2 for another and saw fewer instances, but it would still pop up randomly.

We’ve since had to bite the bullet and rework out status frames and use low frequency and only run on the Rio2 bus.

A complete teardown of all wiring, replacing almost all components, connectors, checking for frame shorts, wiring shorts, and Falcon case shorts came up empty.

We also believe it is a Rio2 USB issue and have chatted with other teams seeing similar issues.

CTRE was kept in the loop but we never came to a solution. Too late for us to keep trying things to make the Canivore work with the Rio2 right now with an event this weekend.

Some people have suggested removing redundant power from 12v from the PDH for the Canivore might help, others have suggested removing the USB flashdrive they use for logging on the Rio2 helps, but these were two suggestions we didn’t get time to test.

(To be clear I don’t think this is CTRE ’s issue to resolve, but I can talk to them, I can’t exactly talk to NI)

@juchong @AllenGregoryIV @jonahb55 @ozrien

Fyi @Peter_Johnson this is the other reason I really wish more advanced code could still run on the Rio1.0 without memory issues.

Akash_Rastogi:

I really wish more advanced code could still run on the Rio1.0 without memory issues.

I am having no trouble running more advanced code, but it did require memory and process optimization with VisualVM and alike (i prefer InteliJ), however I would never do something like OpenCV imageproc on a rio1 constantly and would on a rio2.

Akash_Rastogi:

suggested removing the USB flashdrive they use for logging on the Rio2 helps

This is correct in theory. After looking at logs we think that using a powered USB hub would work as well, however testing this as a solution is difficult as a positive result would be the error doesn’t happen.

nstrike:

I am having no trouble running more advanced code, but it did require memory and process optimization with VisualVM and alike (i prefer InteliJ), however I would never do something like OpenCV imageproc on a rio1 constantly and would on a rio2.

Yeah time was a Factor for us. Week 1 we just wanted to get running, and for this week we spent too much time on this CAN issue.

We’ll revisit rio1 optimization at some point.

posts.name: Jesse Knight
posts.cooked:
Back in 2017 we tried to have 2 USB cameras (one MS Lifecam, one Logitech 920) on the RIO-1 for drivers to use to see gears with different POVs. We found that both cameras would start to drop out if we set the resolution / rate too high on either camera. This led us to suspect that the RIO-1’s USB interface was severely bandwidth limited. We wound up removing the Logitech camera and set the Lifecam to be low res with higher fps.

Not sure that it is the same thing going on here, but might be worth thinking about during troubleshooting.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
We have had similar issues. In most cases the errors do not seem to cause an issue with robot performance.

We have tried a number of things, but haven’t been able to isolate the problem and we are still looking into it.

posts.name: Brian Scharles Jr
posts.cooked: Are you powering your CANivore only via USB, or also from the 12v terminals on it? We ran ours just over USB durig build season with no problem, and then right before our first regional we experienced intermittency. Giving it 12v power made the issue go away (and is recommended in the CTRE docs, so it is something we should have done from the beginning). We have 4 CANcoders, 9 Krakens and 1 Pigeon 2.0 on the bus.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

I’m curious - is having another device plugged into the USB really an issue?

It should not be. I ask as a data point in troubleshooting this issue. As explained a bit below your post I and a few other CSAs are working on an issue with a team and their CANivore dropping off USB entirely, in that case with a USB storage device attached. (A significant amount of logs and data was gathered to support the reasoning in that case, and we’re far from that here.)

I have no reason to believe the same thing is happening here, but understanding all of what’s on a bus (be it CAN or USB) can provide more understanding of the environment to the person trying to help with a problem on the bus.

TL;DR: Just trying to understand the environment, nothing to read into here.

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: We have the termination resistor soldered and shrink wrapped.

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: The electrical department is currently making a power cable with ferral terminals.

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: We have had years where we had multiple cameras for vision. We learned very quickly about setting the resolution as low as possible.

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: We are currently using the Rio1. The software mentor made the call due to hearing complaints about the Rio2. What those are I will have to ask.

posts.name: Domenico
posts.cooked: We’ve had similar issues with CANivores in the past. Turned out to be faulty. We got in contact with CTRE and quickly got it replaced.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Did you come to a resolution?
